Overview:
       

There is mounting interest in the use of benchmarking to evaluate utility operating performance. Managers use benchmarking to identify opportunities for improving either cost or quality performance. A company’s Board of Directors can use benchmarking to evaluate senior management and set executive bonuses.
Benchmarking is also increasingly used in regulation. Some alternative regulation (AltReg) plans use performance benchmarks directly and reward or penalize companies depending on their measured performance compared to established performance standards. Regulators can use benchmarking as one tool to ensure that rates are just and reasonable in a decade of rising cost pressures. For example, benchmarking can be used to assess the reasonableness of payments for customers, A&G, IT and other services provided by unregulated affiliates.
The rising interest in benchmarking around the world has lead to important advances in benchmarking techniques. A wide range of benchmarking methods are available, however, most studies prepared today fall far short of the best available practices.
This seminar is designed to give participants a solid introduction to benchmarking and its potential role in utility management and regulation. Available methods will be reviewed, and principles and precedents for using benchmarking in regulation will also be analyzed. Considerable attention will be devoted to the application of benchmarking in specific utility businesses.
Who Should Attend
The seminar is designed for management and senior level utility personnel, particularly those responsible for ratemaking, regulation and corporate strategy, as well as members of State, Provincial, and Federal regulatory agencies. A detailed working knowledge of benchmarking is not necessary, although some familiarity with the concepts would be helpful. Utilities and regulators that have already utilized benchmarking are strongly urged to attend and share their views and experiences.
